faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Find answers to common questions about KumoOps
faq.q1: A tool or technology I need isn't listed in the add-ons—do you support it?
faq.a1: In most cases, yes. We support a wide range of tools and technologies. Our default setup is container-based (e.g., Docker/Kubernetes), so we generally don't support workloads that require full Windows Server environments.
faq.q2: What happens to the source code and ownership if I cancel my KumoOps subscription?
faq.a2: You keep ownership. We build on open-source tooling and infrastructure-as-code, and during offboarding we provide you with a copy of the relevant code and configuration. After offboarding, your subscription ends—so ongoing support, updates, and improvements are no longer included.
faq.q3: How can KumoOps be cheaper than a single hire?
faq.a3: Because you're not paying for one generalist—you're getting a team. Our engineers specialize in dedicated areas and we roll out improvements across all customers. When we build a feature or harden a setup, every customer benefits, which drives the cost per customer down significantly.
faq.q4: How is KumoOps different from managed services?
faq.a4: KumoOps is a standardized product, not a highly customized cloud setup. This means lower costs, a broader feature set, and faster onboarding compared to traditional managed services—without sacrificing flexibility.
faq.q5: How is KumoOps different from managed Kubernetes?
faq.a5: KumoOps offers much more than just Kubernetes. We take care of your entire cloud infrastructure, CI/CD pipelines, and all CloudSecOps aspects—so you get a complete solution, not just container orchestration.

foundation_plan_full_description.title: Foundation Plan
foundation_plan_full_description.description:
"These prices are our guideline based on the effort we think is necessary to provide the service. Each customer will receive an individual pricing.
The KumoOps Foundation plan provides essential support for your development team’s cloud operation’s needs. This package is designed to offer consistent and predictable support within the scope of the KumoOps tech stack. More Info can be found in the technical specification part. This plan ensures your team has the foundational support required to manage cloud operations efficiently.

Key Features of the Foundation Plan:
• Package Size: Covers up to 8 developers or 8 applications (for non-microservices architectures). If the number of developers or applications exceeds this limit, the client is obligated to order an upgraded package.
• Foundation Setup and Maintenance: Our Foundation Setup and Maintenance service establishes your cloud operations stack through an internal developer platform that implements infrastructure as code and GitOps principles. We continuously manage your environment by provisioning two stages and validating configuration assets to ensure consistent, secure deployments and ongoing support"

introduction.overview: KumoOps – CloudOps as a Service Foundation plan provides essential support for your development team’s cloud operation's needs. The package leverages a modern internal developer platform, using infrastructure as code to consistently set up and manage container-based environments for every stage of your project.

terminology.definition: When the document mentions an infrastructure component, it refers to cloud infrastructure elements typically built using Terraform modules. We develop, test, and reuse these modules for multiple clients. For example, a database module implements infrastructure-as-code to create databases while managing users and schemas.
These essential support services enable business applications to run on the platform. They include components such as logging, monitoring, and alerting.

These services, developed either by the client or our teams, fulfill specific business functions. They often depend on both the underlying infrastructure and the supporting infrastructure services to operate.

architecture.summary: The Foundation plan architecture is shaped based on many years of cloud experience with customers. It has proven already several times to be a robust and efficient architecture.

key_technologies.name: Infrastructure as Code (IaC)
key_technologies.description: Managing and provisioning infrastructure through code rather than manual processes. Uses proven tools like Terraform to build infrastructure components.

key_technologies.name: GitOps
key_technologies.description: A Version Control System (VCS) with dedicated DevOps repositories serves as the source of truth for applications deployed within the Kubernetes cluster, while the Terraform state file acts as the authoritative reference for the underlying infrastructure. ArgoCD is used to deploy both application and infrastructure charts.

terraform.purpose: Responsible for provisioning a variety of infrastructure resources necessary for hosting services in the cloud.
terraform.operations: Initial provisioning and changes are conducted by updating the terraform code and applying them with terraform. During this part, one Kubernetes cluster per stage is provisioned and ArgoCD is set up.

infrastructure_charts_repo.description: Repository describing which Helm charts should be deployed and how. Follows the ArgoCD App-of-Apps pattern.
infrastructure_charts_repo.purpose: Defines the desired state of Kubernetes resources necessary for provisioning a microservice architecture (e.g., logging, monitoring, routing). Contains supporting services for later business applications hosted on the Kubernetes cluster.
infrastructure_charts_repo.documentation_note: Further information about usage can be found in the KumoOps technical handbook which will be available for each client after signing the contract.

app_charts_repo.description: Repository describing how to deploy business services (e.g., Kotlin or Vue.js microservices). Works like the infrastructure-charts repository but focuses on application/business services.
app_charts_repo.documentation_note: Further information about usage can be found in the KumoOps technical handbook which will be available for each client after signing the contract.

included_components.scope: Comprehensive setup for cloud environments across two stages.

components.name: Kubernetes Cluster
details: Configuration of a single Kubernetes cluster per stage. Multi Availability Zones deployment is possible.
Nodepool configuration tailored to meet specific requirements.
Encryption enabled for all nodes.
Custom resource definitions (CRDs) based on best practices.
Storage class definition configured based on best practices, including default encryption.

components.name: Infrastructure as Code
details: A tool like Terraform, OpenTofu, or Crossplane is used.
If Terraform/OpenTofu is used, the plan includes creation of a remote state bucket with encryption.

components.name: Permissions Management
details: Role and permissions setup following best practices specific to the chosen cloud provider.

components.name: DNS Management
details: Fully managed public DNS solution including configuration, routine maintenance, and proactive monitoring of DNS zones.
Designed to ensure fast resolution, high availability, and security against DNS-based attacks.
Leverages reliable cloud infrastructure and best practices to maintain consistent web presence.

components.name: Private DNS
details: Configuration of a private DNS for internal communication.

components.name: Database Service Setup
details: Installation and configuration of one managed database server (free of charge); multiple databases can be created on this server.
Database initialization as code (Infrastructure as Code for setup).
User management as code (automated user provisioning).
Schema management as code (automated schema provisioning).
Support for Primary/Secondary mode, if required.

components.name: Load Balancer Configuration
details: Setup of a load balancer for traffic distribution with automatic connection to the Kubernetes cluster.

components.name: Certificate Management
details: Implementation of cert-manager (e.g., Let's Encrypt) for SSL/TLS certificates.
One business domain certificate per stage.
One admin domain certificate per stage.
Wildcard certificate management for subdomains.

components.name: Jump Server/Bastion Host
details: Deployment and ongoing support of a jump server to provide controlled and secure access to cloud infrastructure.
Serves as a gateway for administrative tasks, reducing the risk of unauthorized access.

components.name: Monitoring, Alerting, and Logging
details: Installation of one monitoring, alerting, and logging system (e.g., Elastic Stack or Loki Stack).
If Elastic Stack is chosen: includes configuration of ILM (Index Lifecycle Management) policies and full setup following best practices.

components.name: Identity Management System
details: Setup and ongoing support for integrating a single identity provider (e.g., Entra ID, Azure AD) into the environment.
Setup of a technical identity management system with Single Sign-On (SSO).
Token-based access control for tools such as ArgoCD, monitoring, and logging systems.
OIDC proxy setup for admin and business domains.

components.name: Administrator Landing Page
details: A dedicated landing page for administrators to manage resources and configurations.

components.name: Redis Setup
details: Installation and configuration of one Redis instance, if required.

components.name: External Uptime Monitoring
details: Integration of external uptime monitoring for business applications.

components.name: Secret Management System
details: Set up and maintain a secrets management system (e.g., HashiCorp Vault, Azure Keyvault, AWS Secrets Manager).
Securely store and manage sensitive credentials, API keys, and other secrets.
Includes a blueprint and documentation for proper secret injection into business applications.

components.name: GitOps Operations
details: Installation and configuration of GitOps workflows in tools like ArgoCD and Flux.
Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) for ArgoCD, including authentication integration with the identity provider and granular access policies; RBAC needs to be requested from the client.
ArgoCD/Flux bootstrap via Tofu.
Automatically discovers microservices in the application repository (e.g., Kotlin, Angular).
Automatically discovers infrastructure services in the infrastructure repository (e.g., Keycloak, Vault, Traefik).

components.name: Population of container pull secrets
details: Deployment of Kyverno to auto-populate container pull secrets.
Includes automatic injection of Git and Docker image pull secrets.
Does not include the Container Security Best Practices Add-On.

additional_notes.note: For OpenTelekomCloud, an additional third stage (infra or infrastructure) is required. This stage is used to deploy central components such as Identity and Secret Management systems.
